ADF/cofilins actin-depolymerizing factor actin-interacting protein 1 dithiothreitol 1-ethyl-3-(3-diethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide N-hydroxysuccinimide 2-nitro-5-thiobenzoate phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 12), alkylenebis(5,5′-dithio-2-nitrobenzoic acid) 4-morpholinepropanesulfonic acid high pressure liquid chromatography reverse-phase HPLC matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight The actin cytoskeleton plays an essential role in many cellular processes such as cytokinesis, changing of cell shape, endocytosis, and exocytosis. All of these processes are dependent on the correct spatial and temporal organization of the actin cytoskeleton (i.e.its regulated polymerization and depolymerization). These reorganizations of the actin cytoskeleton are regulated by a variety of actin-binding proteins, which in turn are regulated by external stimuli such as Ca2+ levels, phosphoinositides, pH, or reversible phosphorylation (1Hartwig J.H. Kwiatkowski D.J. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1991; 3: 87-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (217) Google Scholar, 2Sun H.-Q. Kwiatkowska K. Yin H.L. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 102-110Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar, 3Bamburg J.R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1999; 15: 185-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (830) Google Scholar). The turnover rates of actin filaments in living cells (reviewed in Ref. 4Zigmond S.H. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1993; 25: 309-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar) are 100–200 times faster than the rate constants determined for pure actin (5Pollard T.D. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 2747-2754Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar). This discrepancy is mainly due to the activity of ADF/cofilins (AC),1 which are able to increase the filament turnover in vitro up to levels found in living cells (6Carlier M.F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar). The essential role of AC in enhancing the turnover of actin filaments has been demonstrated in Listeria motility assays (6Carlier M.F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar, 7Rosenblatt J. Agnew B.J. Abe H. Bamburg J.R. Mitchison T.J. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1323-1332Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar) and in living yeast cells (8Lappalainen P. Drubin D.G. Nature. 1997; 388: 78-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (363) Google Scholar). The AC are a class of small (13–19 kDa) actin-binding proteins, which are ubiquitous in eukaryotes (reviewed in Refs. 4Zigmond S.H. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1993; 25: 309-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar and 9Moon A. Drubin D.G. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1995; 6: 1423-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar). They typically localize to regions of rapid actin assembly like neural growth cones (10Bamburg J.R. Bray D. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 2817-2825Crossref PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar), developing skeletal muscle (11Abe H. Oshima S. Obinata T. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1989; 106: 696-702Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), cell cortex (12Moon A.L. Janmey P.A. Louie A.K. Drubin D.G. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 421-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar,13Abe H. Obinata T. Minamide L.S. Bamburg J.R. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 871-885Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar), ruffling membranes (14Yonezawa N. Nishida E. Koyasu S. Maekawa S. Ohta Y. Yahara I. Sakai H. Cell Struct. Funct. 1987; 12: 443-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar), and cleavage furrow (13Abe H. Obinata T. Minamide L.S. Bamburg J.R. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 871-885Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar, 15Nagaoka R. Abe H. Kusano K. Obinata T. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1995; 30: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). AC have been shown to be essential for the viability ofSaccharomyces cerevesiae (12Moon A.L. Janmey P.A. Louie A.K. Drubin D.G. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 421-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar, 16Iida K. Moriyama K. Matsumoto S. Kawasaki H. Nishida E. Yahara I. Gene (Amst.). 1993; 124: 115-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar), Dictyostelium discoideum (17Aizawa H. Sutoh K. Tsubuki S. Kawashima S. Ishii A. Yahara I. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 10923-10932Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar), Caenorhabtidis elegans (18McKim K.S. Matheson C. Marra M.A. Wakarchuk M.F. Baillie D.L. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1994; 242: 346-357Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar),Xenopus laevis (13Abe H. Obinata T. Minamide L.S. Bamburg J.R. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 132: 871-885Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar), and Drosophila melanogaster(19Gunsalus K.C. Bonaccorsi S. Williams E. Verni F. Gatti M. Goldberg M.L. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 131: 1243-1259Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar). In contrast to other actin-binding proteins, AC are able to form 1:1 complexes with both G- and F-actin (20Nishida E. Maekawa S. Sakai H. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 5307-5313Crossref PubMed Scopus (247) Google Scholar), exhibiting a preference for ADP-actin over ATP-actin (6Carlier M.F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar). The mechanism by which AC depolymerize actin filaments was long controversial. Earlier studies suggested that depolymerization of actin filaments was the result of severing (21Maciver S.K. Zot H.G. Pollard T.D. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1611-1620Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar, 22Hawkins M. Pope B. Maciver S.K. Weeds A.G. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9985-9993Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar), thereby increasing the number of filament ends. This view was challenged when it was shown that AC increase the off-rate for actin subunits at the pointed end of the actin filament (6Carlier M.F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar). The two mechanisms are not mutually exclusive (23Theriot J.A. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1165-1168Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar), and recently a mutagenic study revealed that both mechanisms take place side by side and can be uncoupled (24Pope B.J. Gonsior S.M. Yeoh S. McGough A. Weeds A.G. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 298: 649-661Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). The activity of AC is regulated in various ways. Best characterized is the reversible phosphorylation of a conserved serine residue at the amino terminus (except for yeast and Dictyostelium, where no phosphorylated form of cofilin was found) (25Agnew B.J. Minamide L.S. Bamburg J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 17582-17587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar, 26Moriyama K. Iida K. Yahara I. Genes Cells. 1996; 1: 73-78Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27Blanchoin L. Robinson R.C. Choe S. Pollard T.D. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 295: 203-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). In vertebrates, phosphorylation leads to the inhibition of actin binding in vitro (25Agnew B.J. Minamide L.S. Bamburg J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 17582-17587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar) and to accumulation of actin filaments in vivo (28Arber S. Barbayannis F.A. Hanser H. Schneider C. Stanyon C.A. Bernhard O. Caroni P. Nature. 1998; 393: 805-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (1140) Google Scholar, 29Yang N. Higuchi O. Ohashi K. Nagata K. Wada A. Kangawa K. Nishida E. Mizuno K. Nature. 1998; 393: 809-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (1038) Google Scholar). In vertebrates, phosphorylation is catalyzed through LIM kinase 1 or LIM kinase 2 (28Arber S. Barbayannis F.A. Hanser H. Schneider C. Stanyon C.A. Bernhard O. Caroni P. Nature. 1998; 393: 805-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (1140) Google Scholar, 29Yang N. Higuchi O. Ohashi K. Nagata K. Wada A. Kangawa K. Nishida E. Mizuno K. Nature. 1998; 393: 809-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (1038) Google Scholar), which are regulated by the GTPases Rac and Rho/Cdc42, respectively (28Arber S. Barbayannis F.A. Hanser H. Schneider C. Stanyon C.A. Bernhard O. Caroni P. Nature. 1998; 393: 805-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (1140) Google Scholar, 29Yang N. Higuchi O. Ohashi K. Nagata K. Wada A. Kangawa K. Nishida E. Mizuno K. Nature. 1998; 393: 809-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (1038) Google Scholar, 30Sumi T. Matsumoto K. Takai Y. Nakamura T. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 147: 1519-1532Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar). Regulation of AC thus depends on members of the Rho family GTPases, which are known to regulate the formation of filopodia, lamellipoda, and stress fibers in vertebrate cells (31Hall A. Science. 1998; 279: 509-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (5168) Google Scholar). Additionally, actin binding and depolymerizing activities of AC are regulated by binding of phosphoinositides phosphatidylinositol 1,4,5-monophosphate and PIP2 to the actin binding sites of AC, a process that inhibits AC activity (32Yonezawa N. Nishida E. Iida K. Yahara I. Sakai H. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 8382-8386Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 33Yonezawa N. Homma Y. Yahara I. Sakai H. Nishida E. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17218-17221Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 34Van Troys M. Dewitte D. Verschelde J.L. Goethals M. Vandekerckhove J. Ampe C. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 12181-12189Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Early studies proposed that depolymerization and severing of F-actin by AC is dependent on pH, with more extensive depolymerization at pH 8 than at pH ≤ 7 (22Hawkins M. Pope B. Maciver S.K. Weeds A.G. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9985-9993Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar, 35Yonezawa N. Nishida E. Sakai H. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 14410-14412Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36Hayden S.M. Miller P.S. Brauweiler A. Bamburg J.R. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9994-10004Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). The pH effect depends on the AC protein used, as concluded from more recent studies showing that severing by AC is independent of pH, whereas the critical concentration of the AC-actin complex is increased at higher pH values, an effect that leads to an increase in unpolymerized actin (6Carlier M.F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar, 37Ressad F. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. Carlier M.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 20894-20902Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Binding of human cofilin to actin filaments changes the filament twist by 5° per unit, resulting in a reduced crossover length (38McGough A. Pope B. Chiu W. Weeds A. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 138: 771-781Crossref PubMed Scopus (567) Google Scholar). This structural change prevents binding of tropomyosin (39Bernstein B.W. Bamburg J.R. Cell Motil. 1982; 2: 1-8Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar) or of the mushroom toxin phalloidin (40Nishida E. Iida K. Yonezawa N. Koyasu S. Yahara I. Sakai H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 5262-5266Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar), suggesting that binding of AC and other molecules to actin filaments can be mutually exclusive. InXenopus (41Okada K. Obinata T. Abe H. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 1553-1565Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and yeast (42Rodal A.A. Tetreault J.W. Lappalainen P. Drubin D.G. Amberg D.C. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 145: 1251-1264Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar, 43Iida K. Yahara I. Genes Cells. 1999; 4: 21-32Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar), the actin-interacting protein 1 (Aip1) was recently shown to bind to both actin and cofilin and to enhance the filament disassembly activity of cofilin in vitro. Furthermore, Aip1 is required to restrict cofilin localization to yeast cortical patches, whereas in the absence of Aip1, cofilin is found in actin cables as well (42Rodal A.A. Tetreault J.W. Lappalainen P. Drubin D.G. Amberg D.C. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 145: 1251-1264Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). The original aim of the present study was to identify contact sites of actin and cofilin by thiol-specific cross-linking reactions, using reagents experienced in our laboratory for cross-linking studies with myosin S1 (44Kliche W. Pfannstiel J. Tiepold M. Stoeva S. Faulstich H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10307-10317Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Interestingly, we found that not only the expected actin-cofilin conjugate was formed, but also dimers and oligomers of cofilin in considerable amounts. Self-association of cofilin also occurred in the absence of actin and thus indicated an intrinsic property of cofilin. Disulfide-linked oligomers and dimers were isolated and analyzed for their structure and function. The studies on the structure of the actin-cofilin complex will be presented in a forthcoming paper. Cross-linking reagents 1-ethyl-3-(3-diethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide (EDC), 5,5′-dithiobis (2-nitrobenzoic acid) (Ellman's reagent), andN,N′-p-phenylenedimaleimide were purchased from Sigma. Bis-maleimidohexane was from Pierce. Disposable, reverse-phase C18 minicolumns for peptide purification were from Millipore and used according to the manufacturer's instructions. Endoprotease GluC was purchased from Roche Molecular Biochemicals. PIP2 was purchased from Calbiochem. Actin was purified from rabbit skeletal muscle acetone powder as described (45Pardee J. Spudich J.A. Methods Enzymol. 1982; 85: 164-181Crossref PubMed Scopus (959) Google Scholar) and further purified as Ca-ATP G-actin through Sephacryl-S-300 chromatography at 4 °C in buffer G (5 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8, 0.2 mm ATP, 0.1 mm CaCl2, 0.5 mm DTT, 0.01% NaN3). Recombinant human cofilin in plasmid vector pMW172 was expressed inEscherichia coli strain BL21 (DE3) as described for human ADF (22Hawkins M. Pope B. Maciver S.K. Weeds A.G. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9985-9993Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Cell extract supernatants were filtered through a 0.2-μm filter and purified in the flow-through on Q-Sepharose FF (Amersham Biosciences, Inc.) in ADF buffer (10 mmTris-HCl, pH 8, 3 mm DTT, 0.2 mm EGTA, 1 mm NaN3, 0.1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). Cofilin-containing fractions were concentrated in a stirred cell with a YM 10 membrane (Amicon) and eluted from an SP Sepharose HP column (Amersham Biosciences) equilibrated with 20 mm MOPS, pH 6.6, 0.2 mmEGTA, 5 mm DTT, and 0.01% NaN3 with a 0–0.5m sodium chloride gradient. Purified cofilin was dialyzed against ADF buffer (without phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and stored on ice for up to 4 weeks without any loss of activity. Cofilin concentration was determined spectrophotometrically at 280 nm using a calculated extinction coefficient (ε280 = 12,741) based on the method described for human ADF (22Hawkins M. Pope B. Maciver S.K. Weeds A.G. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9985-9993Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Cross-linking reagents RSS(CH2)nSSR were synthesized as described (44Kliche W. Pfannstiel J. Tiepold M. Stoeva S. Faulstich H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10307-10317Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). For thiol-specific cross-linking experiments, the proteins were passed over a Sephadex G25 column equilibrated with reaction buffer to remove excess DTT. Thiol-specific cross-linking experiments were performed in 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8 (reaction buffer 1), or 10 mm HEPES, pH 6.6 (reaction buffer 2). When cross-linking was performed in the presence of actin, reactions were carried out in buffer G (without DTT) or (for experiments involving F-actin) in 5 mm HEPES, 100 mm NaCl, 2 mmMgCl2, 0.2 mm ATP, 0.1 mmCaCl2, 0.01% NaN3, pH 6.6. Thiol-specific cross-linking reagents RSS(CH2)nSSR, Ellman's reagent and GSSG were dissolved in the corresponding reaction buffer and added to the protein solutions in less than 5% of the total volume. Incubation time was usually 1 h at room temperature unless otherwise indicated. Thiol-specific cross-linking reactions with RSS(CH2)nSSR or Ellman's reagent were quenched by the addition of a 100-fold molar excess of N-ethylmaleimide. EDC/NHS cross-linking experiments were carried out according to Grabarek and Gergely (46Grabarek Z. Gergeley J. Anal. Biochem. 1990; 185: 131-135Crossref PubMed Scopus (705) Google Scholar). Reaction mixtures were analyzed by 12.5% SDS-PAGE (47Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (205531) Google Scholar). Capillary flow viscosimetry was performed in a Cannon capillary viscosimeter at 25 °C, using 11 μmF-actin. After a stable plateau was reached, cofilin monomers or cross-linked cofilin dimers and oligomers in buffer F (5 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8, 0.2 mm ATP, 0.1 mm CaCl2, 1 mm MgCl2, 100 mm KCl, 0.01% NaN3) were added to a final concentration of 11 μm in volumes less than 5% of the total. In control experiments, the same volume of buffer F was added. Recovery of cofilin severing activity was measured after adding a 100-fold molar excess of DTT (in buffer F). Results were expressed as specific viscosity values (η). Light scattering measurements were performed at an angle of 90° and at a wavelength of 520 nm in an Aminco Bowman SPF500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Cofilin monomer, dimers, and oligomers in buffer F (see above) were added to 10 μm F-actin when a stable plateau had been reached, again using volumes less than 5% of the total. Recovery of cofilin severing activity was measured after adding a 100-fold molar excess of DTT (in buffer F). Results were expressed as arbitrary units. For negative staining experiments, F-actin (2 μm) was mixed with cofilin monomers, dimers, or oligomers (2–4 μm) in buffer F using pipettes with cut tips to minimize shearing. Controls were carried out using the same volume of buffer F. Glow-discharged carbon-coated grids were floated on sample drops (20 μl) placed on a strip of parafilm, incubated for 30 min, and rinsed twice with buffer F (for a total of 5 min) before staining with 1% uranyl acetate. Micrographs were taken using a Philips 400T transmission electron microscope at 80 kV. Samples for electron cryomicroscopy were prepared as follows. Actin filaments (2 μm) were incubated for 30 min with cofilin oligomers (2 μm) in buffer F. A 7-μl drop of the sample was applied to glow-discharged holey carbon grids (400 mesh) in a humidified chamber. The grids were blotted with filter paper, plunged in liquid nitrogen-cooled ethane, and stored under liquid nitrogen until use. Micrographs were taken using a Philips CM 12 transmission electron microscope at 100 kV. α-Cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (10 mg/ml dissolved in 50% acetonitrile, 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (v/v)) was used as matrix solution. Peptides from RP-HPLC were further purified and concentrated on Ziptips (Millipore) and applied via a sandwich method on stainless steel sample holders. In brief, 0.7 μl of matrix was dried on a sample spot, followed by 0.7 μl of sample and another 0.7 μl of matrix. MALDI-TOF analysis was performed in the linear, high mass, positive ion mode with time-delayed extraction using a Kratos MALDI IV instrument (Shimadzu). Mass spectra were calibrated using external standards consisting of a mixture of substance P, the fragment 1–4 of angiotensin, oxidized insulin B chain, and ubiquitin. Spectra were recorded and analyzed using the Kratos Kompact software, version 5.2.0. Cross-linking of cofilin (100 μm) was carried out in 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8, for 3 h on ice, with an equimolar concentration of Ellman's reagent. Cross-linked products were separated by HPLC gel filtration chromatography using a Waters 600 HPLC system equipped with a Waters 996 photodiode array. Separation was performed at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min on two TSK 3000-G SW columns (Amersham Biosciences; 7.5 × 600 mm) in series in 0.1m Tris-HCl, 0.1 m NaCl, 0.1% sodium azide, pH 7. Usually, 200 μl of the reaction mixture was injected for a single run. Runs were monitored by following the absorbance at 214 and 280 nm, and collected fractions were identified on 12.5% SDS-PAGE. Oligomer, dimer, and monomer fractions were concentrated by ultrafiltration in Minicon (Amicon) concentrators in a Biofuge A (Haeraeus) at 4000 rpm and dialyzed overnight at 4 °C against the corresponding reaction buffer. In order to label cofilin thiols not participating in the cross-link reaction as carboxynitrophenyldisulfide, reactions were carried out as described above except for a 5-fold excess of Ellman's reagent. The labeled oligomers were purified by HPLC gel filtration chromatography, dialyzed overnight at 4 °C against 0.1m ammonium bicarbonate, pH 8, and lyophilized. Labeled oligomers were dissolved at 1 mg/ml in fresh prepared 0.1 mammonium bicarbonate, pH 8, and submitted to proteolytic fragmentation for 12 h at room temperature by adding 2% (w/w) endoprotease Glu-C (Roche Molecular Biosystems). Digestion was terminated by freezing in liquid nitrogen followed by lyophilization. Peptides were dissolved in 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid and purified by RP-HPLC on a Nucleosil C18 column (0.4 × 25 cm; Knauer), using an acetonitrile/trifluoroacetic acid buffer system (buffer A: 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid; buffer B: 90% acetonitrile, 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (v/v)) at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. Labeled peptides were identified by their absorption at 330 nm and analyzed by mass spectroscopy and Edman degradation. A stock solution of PIP2 (2 mg/ml; Calbiochem) was prepared as suspension in H2O by extensive sonication at 37 °C in a Sonorex R100TH sonicator and stored under N2 atmosphere at −80 °C. Immediately before use, stock solutions were thawed in a water bath at 37 °C and resonicated for 15 min at 37 °C. Reaction of recombinant human cofilin with the zero-length cross-linker Ellman's reagent (5,5′-dithio-2-nitrobenzoic acid) leads to the formation of dimers, trimers, and higher oligomers of cofilin even at equimolar concentrations of cross-linker and protein (Fig.1). The frequently used cross-linking reagent EDC achieved the formation of dimers as well, but higher oligomers were almost absent (Fig. 1). In addition, the carbodiimide reaction required a high excess of reagent and a prolonged reaction time. Oligomeric cofilin was likewise formed when thiol-specific cross-linking reagents of the type RSS(CH2)nSSR (44Kliche W. Pfannstiel J. Tiepold M. Stoeva S. Faulstich H. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 10307-10317Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar) were used. Disulfide-linked oligomers were soluble as long asn was ≤ 3 or when Ellman's reagent was used, but they precipitated with reagents of n ≥ 5, or with other thiol-specific cross-linkers such asN,N′-p-phenylenedimaleimide or bis-maleimidohexane. Since there is agreement that covalence between two proteins is formed only in cases when the proteins form a complex in solution, we conclude that cofilin has the intrinsic property of self-association. Furthermore, the successful reaction with Ellman's reagent leads to a zero-length disulfide bond between the cofilin units, indicating that in cofilin dimers and oligomers two thiol groups must come as close as 2 Å. Tetreault J.W. Lappalainen P. Drubin D.G. Amberg D.C. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 145: 1251-1264Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). For the following experiments, Ellman's reagent was chosen as the oxidizing agent, since it was the most effective of the reagents tested. When cofilin concentration was varied in the range of 2–50 μm, we found that yield of dimers and oligomers decreased with decreasing cofilin concentration but that even at a concentration of 2 μm dimers and trimers were formed (Fig.2). This suggests thatKa of cofilin self-association is in the micromolar range and thus slightly above that of the G-actin-cofilin complex (24Pope B.J. Gonsior S.M. Yeoh S. McGough A. Weeds A.G. J. Mol. We therefore carried out cross-linking reactions with 1 eq of Ellman's reagent at pH 6.6 and 8. Since disulfide exchange reactions are faster at pH 8 than at pH 6.6 (due to the higher concentration of the reacting thiolate anion), we extended the reaction time to 24 h. We found that self-association of cofilin takes place at both pH 6.6 and 8 but that it is favored at higher pH (data not shown). Since Ellman's reagent has an oxidation potential considerably higher than most of the naturally occurring disulfides, we assayed whether GSSG might represent a possible, physiological oxidizing agent. As expected from its lower oxidation potential, we found that GSSG was less effective in cross-linking and showed almost no effect when used at equimolar concentrations. However, when GSSG was used at a 10-fold excess, cofilin dimers and trimers were formed to an extent similar to that with 1 eq of Ellman's reagent (Fig.3a). As with Ellman's reagent, GSSG-induced cofilin oligomerization was less pronounced at pH 6.6 than at pH 8 (data not shown). We further assayed whether cofilin dimers and oligomers were formed with Ellman's reagent in the presence of actin. We found that at pH 8 there was almost no difference between oligomer formation in the presence or absence of actin with Ellman's reagent, whereas at pH 6.6, self-association of cofilin was less pronounced (Fig. 3b). Similar results were obtained when GSSG was used as the cross-linking reagent (data not shown). To see whether self-association of cofilin modulated its biological activity, we separated the reaction products obtained from cofilin and Ellman's reagent by HPLC gel filtration chromatography (Fig. 4) and analyzed the peak fractions by SDS-PAGE (Fig. 4, inset). Database protection laws in Europe may have produced a modest, one-time growth spurt for commercial providers. Unfortunately, Europe's new database laws have also produced significant problems including overprotection of low-value data (e.g., telephone books), new barriers to database integration, and further erosion of the public domain. The authors of this Policy Forum caution that these problems could cripple commercial and academic science.

Episodic ataxia type 1 (EA-1) is a neurological disorder arising from mutations in the Kv1.1 potassium channel α-subunit. EA-1 patients exhibit substantial phenotypic variability resulting from at least 14 distinct EA-1 point mutations. We found that EA-1 missense mutations generate mutant Kv1.1 subunits with folding and intracellular trafficking properties indistinguishable from wild-type Kv1.1. However, the single identified EA-1 nonsense mutation exhibits intracellular aggregation and detergent insolubility. This phenotype can be transferred to co-assembled Kv1 α- and Kvβ-subunits associated with Kv1.1 in neurons. These results suggest that as in many neurodegenerative disorders, intracellular aggregation of misfolded Kv1.1-containing channels may contribute to the pathophysiology of EA-1. Episodic ataxia type-1 (EA-1)1 is a neurological syndrome that arises during infancy and persists throughout life. This disorder is characterized by continuous myokymia and brief and sometimes frequent attacks of cerebellar ataxia, resulting in imbalanced movements. Also note that the bulk of the electrophoretic microheterogeneity of wild-type Kv1.1 is lacking in Kv1.1ΔC79, presumably due to elimination of C-terminal phosphorylation sites (40Jing J. Peretz T. Singer-Lahat D. Chikvashvili D. Thornhill W.B. Lotan I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 14021-14024Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Each of the EA-1 mutants was expressed in COS-1 cells and subjected to immunofluorescence staining. Wild-type Kv1.1 expressed in transfected mammalian cells is localized to the endoplasmic reticulum (33Manganas L.N. Trimmer J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 29685-29693Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar), such that immunofluorescence staining of cells expressing wild-type Kv1.1 yields a diffuse, reticular perinuclear pattern (Fig. 1C). In contrast, Kv1.1ΔC79, while also perinuclear, is present in large membranous aggregates (Fig. 1C). A detailed quantitative analysis of the number of transfected cells exhibiting this aggregated staining pattern, which was defined as the aggregation index, revealed that the majority (56 ± 6.1%) of the cells expressing Kv1.1ΔC79 had obvious intracellular aggregates as shown in Fig.1C, whereas these were present in only 6.0% (± 1.0%) of the cells expressing wild-type Kv1.1. Each of the 13 missense EA-1 mutants resembled wild-type Kv1.1 in that aggregates were observed in 6% or fewer of the expressing cells (Fig. 1B). To determine whether these differences between wild-type Kv1.1 and Kv1.1ΔC79 existed in neurons, transfected cultured primary hippocampal neurons were subjected to immunofluorescence staining. Neurons expressing Kv1.1ΔC79 formed perinuclear aggregates of the mutant protein similar to those observed in COS-1 cells (Fig. 1D, right panel), whereas cells expressing wild-type Kv1.1 did not (Fig. 1D, left panel). These results suggest that the mechanisms that mediate folding of Kv1 channels in COS-1 cells and cultured neurons are similar. These biochemical and immunohistochemical results together show that the 13 different missense mutations found in Kv1.1 from EA-1 patients resemble wild-type Kv1.1 and do not exhibit obvious characteristics of protein misfolding. In contrast, the truncated Kv1.1 generated by the R417STOP nonsense mutation found in patients with the drug-resistant form of EA-1 exhibits two hallmarks of misfolding, detergent insolubility and intracellular aggregation. To investigate further the biochemical properties of Kv1.1ΔC79 channels, transfected COS-1 cells were subjected to extraction in increasing concentrations of Triton X-100. Almost half of the total Kv1.1ΔC79 pool was insoluble in 0.1% Triton X-100 (Fig.2A). A 10-fold increase in Triton X-100 concentration did eventually solubilize the bulk of the Kv1.1ΔC79 pool, consistent with effects of increased Triton X-100 on solubility of other misfolded proteins (39Marquardt T. Helenius A. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 505-513Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the Kv1.1ΔC79 polypeptide pool in COS-1 cells consisted of two populations, one form with an apparent mass of 55 kDa, and a second form of 50 kDa. These forms differed in their detergent solubility properties, such that the 50-kDa form was consistently enriched in the detergent-insoluble fraction (Fig. 2A). The Kv1.1-deduced amino acid sequence contains a single consensusN-linked glycosylation site in the extracellular segment between the S1 and S2 transmembrane regions (41Chandy K.G. Gutman G.A. North R.A. Ligand- and Voltage-gated Ion Channels. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1995: 1-71Google Scholar). Previously, we found that Kv1.1 is N-linked glycosylated at this site (42Shi G. Trimmer J.S. J. Membr. Biol. 1999; 168: 265-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). To determine whether the two populations of Kv1.1ΔC79 seen in COS-1 cells were different in N-glycosylation, membrane extracts were treated with PNGase F, an enzyme that cleaves N-linked sugars from glycoproteins. PNGase F treatment of Kv1.1ΔC79 reveals that the higher molecular weight Kv1.1ΔC79 pool isN-glycosylated, whereas the lower molecular weight pool is resistant to PNGase F digestion and presumably unglycosylated, such that the electrophoretic mobility of the higher molecular weight pool shifts to that of the lower molecular weight pool upon PNGase F digestion (Fig. 2B). Similar results were obtained with endoglycosidase H (Fig. 2B), consistent with the high mannose oligosaccharide present on the ER-localized Kv1.1ΔC79 (Fig.2B). Kv1.1ΔC79 was insensitive to neuraminidase treatment (Fig. 2B), consistent with its ER retention. Although wild-type Kv1.1 expressed in heterologous cells exhibits substantial microheterogeneity in molecular weight on SDS gels (Fig.1B), this is not due to differential glycosylation (43Deal K.K. Lovinger D.M. Tamkun M.M. J. Neurosci. 1994; 14: 1666-1676Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and each of the components of the wild-type Kv1.1 pool is sensitive to both PNGase F and endoglycosidase H (42Shi G. Trimmer J.S. J. Membr. Biol. 1999; 168: 265-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). These results together show that Kv1.1ΔC79 is not as efficiently N-glycosylated as is wild-type Kv1.1. Moreover, the lower molecular weight unglycosylated pool of Kv1.1ΔC79 exhibits greater resistance to detergent solubilization. These results are consistent with a model whereby the C-terminal truncation of Kv1.1ΔC79 allosterically affects the folding of the S1–S2 segment and the subsequent addition of anN-linked oligosaccharide chain at this site. To define the origin of the Kv1.1ΔC79 intracellular aggregates, transfected COS-1 cells were double-labeled for the resident ER protein calnexin, and a marker of the Golgi apparatus, the lectin Lens culinaris agglutinin (44Hsu V.W. Shah N. Klausner R.D. Cell. 1992; 69: 625-635Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). Calnexin staining co-localized with the perinuclear aggregates containing mutant Kv1.1ΔC79 channels (Fig.2C) whereas L. culinaris agglutinin staining did not (data not shown). These immunofluorescence results suggest that the intracellular Kv1.1ΔC79 aggregates are derived from ER. To measure further the folding state of Kv1.1ΔC79, we undertook binding studies with two neurotoxins (α-DTX and DTXK) that exhibit high affinity binding to Kv1.1. Binding sites for125I-α-DTX were detected on the cell surface of BHK cells expressing wild-type Kv1.1 (Fig. 2D). Exposure of total cellular binding sites by sonication yielded an 18-fold increase in125I-α-DTX binding in Kv1.1-expressing cells (Fig.2D), consistent with the intracellular retention of the bulk of the expressed Kv1.1 protein (33Manganas L.N. Trimmer J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 29685-29693Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar). Negligible cell surface binding was observed in cells expressing Kv1.1ΔC79, and cell fragmentation by sonication did not lead to an appreciable increase in total toxin binding (Fig. 2D). Immunoblot analyses performed on BHK cell membranes showed that Kv1.1 and Kv1.1ΔC79 were expressed at similar levels in the transfected BHK cells, consistent with results from COS-1 cells (see Fig. 1B). Negligible125I-DTXK binding was observed to intact or sonicated cells expressing Kv1.1ΔC79 (data not shown). These results are consistent with the notion that misfolding of Kv1.1ΔC79 alters the DTX-binding site, which is contributed by residues in the external mouth of the channel pore. Unassembled and misassembled membrane protein complexes are retained in the ER and degraded by quality control mechanisms. To determine whether the distinct phenotype of Kv1.1ΔC79 relative to wild-type Kv1.1 and the other EA-1 mutants is simply due to defects in subunit assembly, membrane extracts containing Kv1.1 or Kv1.1ΔC79 channels were analyzed on nondenaturing continuous sucrose density gradients (45Spencer R.H. Sokolov Y. Li H. Takenaka B. Milici A.J. Aiyar J. Nguyen A. Park H. Jap B.K. Hall J.E. Gutman G.A. Chandy K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 2389-2395Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). Extractions were performed in 1% Triton X-100 to dissociate insoluble aggregates of Kv1.1ΔC79 such that the bulk of both Kv1.1 and Kv1.1ΔC79 were now soluble (Fig. 2A). We found that the peak of wild-type Kv1.1 immunoreactivity appeared in the gradient fraction containing proteins of apparent molecular mass of 165–285 kDa, with no evidence of pools of monomeric subunits. These results are consistent with the calculated molecular mass of Kv1.1 tetramers of 225 kDa, and with previous studies showing efficient assembly of Kv1.1 expressed in mammalian cells (43Deal K.K. Lovinger D.M. Tamkun M.M. J. Neurosci. 1994; 14: 1666-1676Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The major peak of Kv1.1ΔC79 co-migrated with wild-type Kv1.1, and peaks corresponding to unassembled monomeric subunits were not detected (Fig. 2E). These data suggest that the bulk of Kv1.1ΔC79 that could be solubilized in 1% Triton X-100 was present as tetramers (the calculated molecular mass of Kv1.1ΔC79 tetramers is 191 kDa). The Kv1.1ΔC79 sample also contained higher molecular weight species, perhaps corresponding to Kv1.1ΔC79 aggregates soluble in 1% Triton X-100. These results show that both wild-type Kv1.1 and Kv1.1ΔC79 subunits are efficiently assembled, although higher molecular weight species, presumably corresponding to aggregated channel complexes, are also observed for Kv1.1ΔC79 but not wild-type Kv1.1. Previously, it has been shown that the efficiency of intracellular trafficking of a number of integral membrane proteins, including mutant CFTR, is temperature-sensitive, implying that a polypeptide folding step was affected (46Machamer C.E. Rose J.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 5955-5960Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 47Paulson H.L. Claudio T. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 1705-1717Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 48Denning G.M. Anderson M.P. Amara J.F. Marshall J. Smith A.E. Welsh M.J. Nature. 1992; 358: 761-764Crossref PubMed Scopus (1061) Google Scholar). Chemical chaperones, such as the polyhydric alcohol glycerol, have also been used as folding indicators, as glycerol can stabilize protein conformation and increase both the rate of in vitro protein refolding and the kinetics of oligomeric assembly (49Shelanski M.L. Gaskin F. Cantor C.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1973; 70: 765-768Crossref PubMed Scopus (1971) Google Scholar, 50Gekko K. Timasheff S.N. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 4677-4686Crossref PubMed Scopus (443) Google Scholar, 51Gekko K. Timasheff S.N. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 4667-4676Crossref PubMed Scopus (1109) Google Scholar, 52Sawano H. Koumoto Y. Ohta K. Sasaki Y. Segawa S. Tachibana H. FEBS Lett. 1992; 303: 11-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Moreover, a combination of lowered temperature and glycerol addition yields dramatic improvements in the trafficking of the misfolded ΔF508 mutation of CFTR (36Sato S. Ward C.L. Krouse M.E. Wine J.J. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 635-638Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (465) Google Scholar, 48Denning G.M. Anderson M.P. Amara J.F. Marshall J. Smith A.E. Welsh M.J. One of the prominent effects of the Src kinase is to reduce cell adhesion. The small GTPase, R-Ras, affects cell adhesion by maintaining integrin activity, and the ability of R-Ras to do so can be regulated by phosphorylation of a tyrosine residue located in its effector domain by an Eph receptor kinase (Zou, J. X., Wang, B., Kalo, M. S., Zisch, A. H., Pasquale, E. B., and Ruoslahti, E. (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 96, 13813–13818). Here we show that Src regulates cell adhesion through R-Ras and integrins. Reduced substrate attachment of 293T cells transfected with the cDNA for an activated form of Src (v-Src) was accompanied by phosphorylation of endogenous R-Ras. v-Src also phosphorylated R-Ras in vitro. An activated form of Src similar to one that has been found in human cancers, Src527, shared with v-Src the ability to phosphorylate R-Ras. Stronger R-Ras phosphorylation was seen in Madin-Darby canine kidney cells cells transformed with temperature-sensitive v-Src at the permissive temperature than at the non-permissive temperature, and R-Ras and Src co-immunoprecipitated at the permissive temperature. Mutation analysis showed that the Src phosphorylation site in R-Ras was tyrosine 66, the position critical to the ability of R-Ras to support integrin activity. Finally, activated R-Ras in which tyrosine 66 is mutated to phenylalanine rendered cells partially resistant to the effects of Src on cell adhesion. Regulation of cell adhesion by Src through R-Ras may be at least partially responsible for the reduced adhesion and the resulting increased invasiveness of Src-transformed cells. One of the prominent effects of the Src kinase is to reduce cell adhesion. The small GTPase, R-Ras, affects cell adhesion by maintaining integrin activity, and the ability of R-Ras to do so can be regulated by phosphorylation of a tyrosine residue located in its effector domain by an Eph receptor kinase (Zou, J. X., Wang, B., Kalo, M. S., Zisch, A. H., Pasquale, E. B., and Ruoslahti, E. (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 96, 13813–13818). Here we show that Src regulates cell adhesion through R-Ras and integrins. Reduced substrate attachment of 293T cells transfected with the cDNA for an activated form of Src (v-Src) was accompanied by phosphorylation of endogenous R-Ras. v-Src also phosphorylated R-Ras in vitro. An activated form of Src similar to one that has been found in human cancers, Src527, shared with v-Src the ability to phosphorylate R-Ras. Stronger R-Ras phosphorylation was seen in Madin-Darby canine kidney cells cells transformed with temperature-sensitive v-Src at the permissive temperature than at the non-permissive temperature, and R-Ras and Src co-immunoprecipitated at the permissive temperature. Mutation analysis showed that the Src phosphorylation site in R-Ras was tyrosine 66, the position critical to the ability of R-Ras to support integrin activity. Finally, activated R-Ras in which tyrosine 66 is mutated to phenylalanine rendered cells partially resistant to the effects of Src on cell adhesion. Regulation of cell adhesion by Src through R-Ras may be at least partially responsible for the reduced adhesion and the resulting increased invasiveness of Src-transformed cells. extracellular signal-regulated kinase mitogen-activated protein kinase glutathione S-transferase Madin-Darby canine kidney cells temperature-sensitive Reduced adhesiveness is one of the hallmarks of malignantly transformed cells, as exemplified by the rounding up of transformed cells in culture. Transformed cells elaborate less fibronectin matrix than their normal counterpart cells. These properties are thought to be important in facilitating the ability of malignant cells to leave their original site and invade other tissues (1Hynes R.O. Fibronectins. Springer-Verlag, New York Inc., New York1990Crossref Google Scholar, 2Ruoslahti E. Adv. Cancer Res. 1999; 76: 1-20Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Cell adhesion and extracellular matrix assembly are largely controlled by integrins, a family of heterodimeric membrane proteins that mediate cell-extracellular matrix interactions (3Giancotti F.G. Ruoslahti E. Science. 1999; 285: 1028-1032Crossref PubMed Scopus (3794) Google Scholar). Cells control the ability of their integrins to bind to extracellular ligands. Thus, certain cells can convert from non-adherent to highly adherent cells through integrin activation. This happens when platelets are activated and aggregate to initiate blood clotting and when leukocytes adhere to the vascular endothelium at inflammatory sites (4Springer T.A. Cell. 1994; 76: 301-314Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (6381) Google Scholar,5Schwartz M.A. Schaller M.D. Ginsberg M.H. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 549-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (1466) Google Scholar). The degree of activation of integrins in adherent cells can also vary (5Schwartz M.A. Schaller M.D. Ginsberg M.H. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 549-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (1466) Google Scholar). Src and the oncogenic Ras proteins are among the oncoproteins that reduce cell adhesion and fibronectin matrix formation (1Hynes R.O. Fibronectins. Springer-Verlag, New York Inc., New York1990Crossref Google Scholar, 2Ruoslahti E. Adv. Cancer Res. 1999; 76: 1-20Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), presumably by affecting integrin activity. A mechanism whereby H-Ras interferes with integrin activity through the ERK1 MAPK pathway has been proposed recently (6Hughes P.E. Renshaw M.W. Pfaff M. Forsyth J. Keivens V.M. Schwartz M.A. Ginsberg M.H. Cell. 1997; 88: 521-530Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar). R-Ras, a small intracellular GTPase that is related to H-Ras and K-Ras, but that is only weakly oncogenic (7Marte B.M. Rodriguez-Viciana P. Wennstrom S. Warne P.H. Downward J. Curr. Biol. 1996; 7: 63-70Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 8Bos J.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1333: M19-M31Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar, 9Vojtek A.B. Der C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19925-19928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (498) Google Scholar), can control integrin function (10Zhang Z. Vuori K. Wang H. Reed J.C. Ruoslahti E. Cell. 1996; 85: 61-69Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar). The ability of R-Ras to control integrin activity can be regulated by phosphorylation. An Eph receptor, EphB2, phosphorylates a tyrosine residue in the effector domain of R-Ras and, as the phosphorylated R-Ras no longer supports integrin activity, cell-extracellular matrix adhesion is lost upon activation of EphB2 (11Zou J.X. Wang B. Kalo M.S. Zisch A.H. Pasquale E.B. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13813-13818Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Another Eph receptor, EphA2, has also been reported to down-regulate integrin-mediated adhesion (12Miao H. Burnett E. Kinch M. Simon E. Wang B. Nature Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 62-69Crossref PubMed Scopus (470) Google Scholar). Based on the sequence of the kinase domain, the substrate specificity of the Eph receptor kinases is predicted to be similar to that of non-receptor tyrosine kinases such as Src (13Kalo M.S. Pasquale E.B. Cell Tissue Res. 1999; 298: 1-9Crossref Scopus (61) Google Scholar); and Src is associated with integrin complexes in focal adhesions (14Fincham V.J. Brunton V.G. Frame M.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6518-6536Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 15Schaller M.D. Hildebrand J.D. Parsons J.T. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 3489-3505Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). In this paper, we examine the possibility that Src might also regulate integrin activity by phosphorylating the effector domain tyrosine in R-Ras. We show that v-Src and an activated mutant Src protein both phosphorylate the critical tyrosine residue in R-Ras in vitro and in cells and that Src can be co-immunoprecipitated with R-Ras from cell extracts. A variant R-Ras that cannot be phosphorylated in the effector domain renders cells partially resistant to the cell adhesion-reducing effects of activated Src. These results indicate that the R-Ras pathway is, at least in part, responsible for the reduced adhesiveness of Src-transformed cells. This may be a contributory mechanism in tumor invasion. The kinase-inactive v-Src plasmid, pcDNA3-v-srcK295R, was generated by mutating a lysine at position 295 to an arginine in the v-Src expression plasmid, pcDNA3-v-src, by using a QuikChange Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (Stratagene). Construction of Myc-tagged forms of wild-type R-Ras and the mutants R-RasY66F and R-Ras66YE, and the plasmids for the expression of GST-R-Ras and GST-H-Ras have also been described (11Zou J.X. Wang B. Kalo M.S. Zisch A.H. Pasquale E.B. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13813-13818Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 1311-1323Crossref PubMed Scopus (565) Google Scholar, 17Turner D.L. Weintraub H. Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 1434-1447Crossref PubMed Scopus (951) Google Scholar) was a gift from Dr. Christine Holt. A monoclonal anti-Myc antibody and a polyclonal anti-R-Ras antibody used for immunoblotting were from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. A polyclonal anti-Myc antibody used for immunoprecipitation was from Upstate Biotechnology, and an anti-v-Src antibody (clone 327) used for immunoblotting was from Oncogene Research Products. An anti-v-Src antibody (clone GD11) used for immunoprecipitation was obtained from Upstate Biotechnology. An anti-R-Ras antiserum was prepared by immunizing a rabbit with bacterially produced GST-R-Ras protein. Specific antibodies were purified from the antiserum on a GST-R-Ras affinity column. The antibody was then absorbed on a GST-H-Ras affinity column to eliminate any possible cross-reactivity with H-Ras. The antibody immunoblotted a single protein band of the appropriate size in 293 cells transfected with R-Ras, but not in cells transfected with H-Ras, Rap-1, or Ral. Transient transfections were performed with 293T cells. Cells were transfected in 10-cm plates at 60% confluency with 5–10 μg of each plasmid DNA by using Superfect Transfection Reagent (Qiagen). The total amount of transfected DNA was kept constant by addition of pcDNA3. To examine cell morphology, the transfected cells were marked by co-transfection with 1 μg of the enhanced green fluorescent protein vector pEGFP (CLONTECH). Cell extracts were prepared in lysis buffer (50 mm Hepes, pH 7.6, 1% Triton X-100, 0.1% SDS, 1% sodium deoxycholate, 2 mmEDTA, 2 mm EGTA, 150 mm NaCl, 50 mmNaF, 20 mm sodium vanadate, and 10% glycerol (v/v)). Protease inhibitor phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and the protease inhibitor mixture (Sigma) were added to the lysis buffer prior to the use. For immunoprecipitation, cell lysates were first incubated with antibodies at 4 °C for 1.5 h and then incubated with GammaBind-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences, Inc.) or Protein A-Sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for another 1.5 h at 4 °C. Immunoprecipitates were boiled in SDS-containing sample buffer, separated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred to Immobilon membranes (Millipore). An anti-phosphotyrosine antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (PY-20H; Transduction Laboratories) was used for immunoblotting at 1:2000 dilution. An anti-Myc antibody (9E10) and anti-R-Ras antibody, both from Santa Cruz Biotechnology were used at a dilution 1:1000, followed by a secondary goat-anti-mouse IgG antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase. An anti-v-Src antibody (Oncogene) was used at 10 μg/ml, followed by protein A conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (Sigma). Immunoblots were developed by enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham Biosciences, Inc.). v-Src immunoprecipitates were split into equal amounts and washed with a kinase buffer consisting of 50 mm Hepes, pH 7.6, 20 mm MnCl2, 20 mm MgCl2, 0.25 mmNa3VO4, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 5 μg/ml aprotinin, and 2.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Kinase reactions were carried out for 15 min at room temperature in kinase buffer containing 1 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP. The kinase reaction was stopped by adding SDS sample buffer. Microtiter 96-well plates (Linbro/Titertek) were pre-coated with 2.5 μg/ml fibronectin (Chemicon), 20 μg/ml type I collagen (Collaborative Biomedical Products) overnight at 4 °C. The wells were then blocked with 1% bovine serum albumin. Forty-eight hours after transfection, cultured cells were detached with 2.5 mm EDTA, washed with serum-free medium, and added to the coated wells (1 × 105 cells/well). Following incubation at 37 °C for 1 h, the wells were washed with serum-free medium, and attached cells were fixed and stained with 0.5% crystal violet in methanol-H2O. The crystal violet incorporated into cells was collected in 1% SDS and quantified by measuringA at 590 nm. The ability of v-Src to phosphorylate R-Ras was studied in 293T cells transfected with v-Src. Green fluorescent protein (EGFP) vector was co-transfected to identify the cells that had received the vector. The transfected cells showed morphological changes typical of Src transformation, rounding of the cells and growth into higher saturation density (not shown). A kinase-inactive v-Src and the vector alone caused no changes. Immunoprecipitation of R-Ras from these cells showed that R-Ras was phosphorylated in the cells transfected with v-Src, but not in cells transfected with kinase-inactive v-Src, v-SrcK295R (Fig.1). Incubation of a full-length R-Ras GST fusion protein with v-Src immunoprecipitates from v-Src-transfected 293T cells also resulted in phosphorylation of R-Ras, showing that v-Src can also phosphorylate R-Ras in vitro (Fig.2).Figure 2Phosphorylation of R-Ras by v-Src in vitro. Both intact GST-R-Ras and a fragment containing the GST moiety and the amino-terminal portion of R-Ras were phosphorylated.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) We next examined the ability of c-Src527, an activated mutant c-Src, to phosphorylate R-Ras. We found that R-Ras immunoprecipitated from cells transfected with this variant c-Src was tyrosine-phosphorylated to an extent similar to R-Ras from v-Src cells (not shown). MDCK cells transformed with temperature-sensitive (ts) v-Src were used to further analyze the dependence of R-Ras phosphorylation on Src activity. R-Ras was more heavily phosphorylated when these cells were grown at the permissive temperature than at the non-permissive temperature, indicating a correlation between the phosphorylation of R-Ras and Src activity (Fig. 3). The R-Ras phosphorylation paralleled the temperature-sensitive morphological changes of these cells (not shown). R-Ras immunoprecipitates from the ts-v-Src-transformed MDCK cells contained v-Src when the cells had been grown at the permissive temperature (Fig. 4). No v-Src was detected in association with R-Ras in MDCK cells cultured at the non-permissive temperature. Thus, the binding of v-Src to R-Ras in cells is specific and depends on the kinase activity, or phosphorylation status, of v-Src. Alternatively, the conformation of v-Src at the non-permissive temperature may not be comparable with binding to R-Ras. The Eph receptor, EphB2, can phosphorylate R-Ras primarily in tyrosine 66 (Tyr-66), which is located in the effector domain of R-Ras (11Zou J.X. Wang B. Kalo M.S. Zisch A.H. Pasquale E.B. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13813-13818Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). We used variant R-Ras proteins mutated at Tyr-66 to study the site of Src phosphorylation in R-Ras. The results showed that only R-Ras containing Tyr-66 was phosphorylated in cells co-transfected with c-Src527 or v-Src and one of the R-Ras variants (Fig. 5,A and B). Immunoblotting showed that the variants were equally expressed in the transfected cells. Src interacted with R-Ras regardless of whether the residue at position 66 could be phosphorylated (Fig. 6). These results indicate that Tyr-66 is the main, perhaps sole, Src phosphorylation site in R-Ras. Equal amounts of cell lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-v-Src monoclonal antibody (GD11), and the immunoprecipitates were probed by immunoblotting. YF, Y66F mutant. YE, Y66E mutant. V, empty vector.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) We have shown earlier that the R-RasY66F mutant is active in supporting integrin activity (11Zou J.X. Wang B. Kalo M.S. Zisch A.H. Pasquale E.B. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13813-13818Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). We reasoned that, if phosphorylation of R-Ras by Src contributes to the decreased cell adhesion of Src-transformed cells, R-RasY66F should counteract this effect of Src, because its activity cannot be suppressed by phosphorylation at Tyr-66. We used the activated form R-Ras38V to prepare this mutant because the activated R-Ras more efficiently increases the adhesion of poorly adherent cells than wild-type R-Ras (10Zhang Z. Vuori K. Wang H. Reed J.C. Ruoslahti E. Cell. 1996; 85: 61-69Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar). Cell attachment assays showed that expression of v-Src or c-Src527 decreased the attachment of 293 cells to fibronectin by 60–70% (Fig. 7). As the transfection efficiency in the 293 cells was about 70% (not shown), this level of reduction indicates that the transfected cells have become essentially non-adhesive. The ability of v-Src to decrease cell adhesion was partially suppressed by the co-expression of the R-Ras38VY66F mutant, but not by R-Ras38V (Fig. 7). Similar results were obtained with c-Src527, and by plating the cells on type I collagen instead of fibronectin (data not shown). These results suggest that activated Src inhibits cell adhesion through phosphorylation of R-Ras, which suppresses the ability of R-Ras to support integrin activity. We show here that activated Src can phosphorylate a tyrosine residue in R-Ras that is located in the effector domain of R-Ras. The phosphorylation of this effector domain residue affects the ability of R-Ras to regulate integrin activation. As a consequence, integrin-mediated cell adhesion is impaired. This mechanism may, at least in part, explain the reduced cell adhesion that is characteristic of Src-transformed cells. Earlier results have shown that the activity of endogenous R-Ras is required for cells to maintain their ability to attach to extracellular matrix substrates through integrins (10Zhang Z. Vuori K. Wang H. Reed J.C. Ruoslahti E. Cell. 1996; 85: 61-69Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the ability of the activated EphB2 receptor to decrease cell adhesion is mediated by the phosphorylation of R-Ras (11Zou J.X. Wang B. Kalo M.S. Zisch A.H. Pasquale E.B. Ruoslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13813-13818Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar). EphA2 has a similar effect on cell adhesion (12Miao H. Burnett E. Kinch M. Simon E. Wang B. Nature Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 62-69Crossref PubMed Scopus (470) Google Scholar), indicating that this Eph receptor may also act through R-Ras. The present results indicate that v-Src and constitutively activated c-Src reduce cell adhesion at least in part by the same mechanism as the Eph receptors. Cell transformation by v-Src causes a pleiotropic change in cellular properties, including loss of normal growth control, reduced adhesion and cell rounding. The mechanism underlying this v-Src-induced transformation is still obscure. Previous studies have shown that the ability of v-Src to induce changes in cell structure and morphology is independent of changes in gene expression (18Beug H. Claviez M. Jockusch B.M. Graf T. Cell. 1978; 14: 843-856Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 19Frame M.C. Simpson K. Fincham V.J. Crouch D.H. Cell. 1994; 5: 1177-1184Google Scholar) and, therefore, most likely a direct result of the tyrosine kinase activity of Src. Many of the known v-Src targets are associated with the cellular cytoskeletal network and focal adhesions (14Fincham V.J. Brunton V.G. Frame M.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 6518-6536Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 15Schaller M.D. Hildebrand J.D. Parsons J.T. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 3489-3505Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar, 20McClean G.W. Fincham V.J. Frame M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 23333-23339Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Our results showing that oncogenic Src also phosphorylates R-Ras add a new and potentially important substrate to the list of proteins phosphorylated by Src. The binding of Src to R-Ras is another novel aspect of our findings. The R-Ras variant resistant to Src phosphorylation only partially reversed the effects of oncogenic Src on cell adhesion, suggesting the existence of additional pathways whereby Src can affect cell adhesion. H-Ras, which like Src interferes with integrin activity, regulates integrins through the ERK MAPK pathway (6Hughes P.E. Renshaw M.W. Pfaff M. Forsyth J. Keivens V.M. Schwartz M.A. Ginsberg M.H. Cell. 1997; 88: 521-530Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar). As Src is capable of activating ERK, this pathway could contribute to the effects of Src transformation on cell adhesion. c-Src has been found to be activated in colon cancers metastatic to the liver (21Talmonti M.S. Roh M.S. Curley S.A. Gallick G.E. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 91: 53-60Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar, 22Termuheln P.M. Curley S.A. Talamonti M.S. Saboorian M.H. Gallick G.E. J. Surg. Res. 1993; 54: 293-298Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). A truncating mutation in human c-Src at codon 531 (corresponding to 528 in chicken c-Src) has been found in 12% of cases of advanced human colon cancer (23Irby R.B. Mao W. Coppola D. Kang J. Loubeau J.M. Trudeau W. Karl R. Fujita D.J. Jove R. Yeatman T.J. Nature Genetics. 1999; 21: 187-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar). This mutation activates c-Src, conferring transforming, tumorigenic and metastasis-promoting activity to Src. We tested another similarly activated c-Src mutant, c-Src527 (23Irby R.B. Mao W. Coppola D. Kang J. Loubeau J.M. Trudeau W. Karl R. Fujita D.J. Jove R. Yeatman T.J. Nature Genetics. 1999; 21: 187-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar, 24Cooper J.A. Gould K.L. Cartwright C.A. Hunter T. Science. 1986; 231: 1431-1434Crossref PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar), and found that it phosphorylated R-Ras as effectively as v-Src. As reduced cell adhesion can promote tumor invasion and metastasis (2Ruoslahti E. Adv. Cancer Res. 1999; 76: 1-20Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the Src-R-Ras pathway we describe here may contribute to the oncogenic properties of Src. However, as activation of the αvβ3 integrin has been shown to promote rather than to inhibit metastasis (25Felding-Habermann B. O'Toole T.E. Smith J.W. Fransvea E. Ruggeri Z.M. Ginsberg M.H. Hughes P.E. Pampori N. Shattil S.J. Saven A. Mueller B.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 1853-1858Crossref PubMed Scopus (479) Google Scholar), the effects of the Src-integrin pathway on tumor progression may be complex. Although our results do not address that question, regulating cell adhesion through R-Ras phosphorylation may also be part of the normal function of c-Src. We thank Christine Holt for providing reagents and Andrew Freeman for help with the R-Ras antibodies and immunoblotting.

The Jak family of protein-tyrosine kinases are crucial for the signaling of a large number of different polypeptide ligands, including the interferons, many cytokines, erythropoietin, and growth factors. Through their interaction with receptors, the Jaks initiate a signaling cascade resulting in the activation of gene transcription and ultimately a cellular response to various ligands. In addition to their role in cellular signaling, alteration of Jak activity has been implicated in several disease states. In identifying Jak2-interacting proteins with the yeast two-hybrid system, we cloned the human homologue of theDrosophila melanogaster tumor suppressor gene lethal (2Stark G. Kerr I.M. Williams B.R.G. Silverman R.H. Schrieber R.D. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 227-264Crossref PubMed Scopus (3361) Google Scholar) tumorous imaginal discs, which encodes the protein Tid56.Drosophila Tid56 and its human homologue hTid-1 represent members of the DnaJ family of molecular chaperones. TheTID1 gene encodes two splice variants hTid-1Sand hTid-1L. We confirmed the interaction between Jak2 and hTid-1S or hTid-1L by immunoprecipitation from COS-1 cells expressing these proteins. The interaction between endogenous hTid-1 and Jak2 was shown in HEp2 cells. We further showed that hTid-1 interacts with the human interferon-γ (Hu-IFN-γ) receptor subunit IFN-γR2. In addition, using a chimeric construct where the extracellular domain of IFN-γR2 was fused to the kinase domain of Jak2, we showed that hTid-1 binds more efficiently to the chimera with an active kinase domain than to a similar construct with an inactive kinase domain. Additionally, the data demonstrate that hTid-1 isoforms as well as Jak2 interact with Hsp70/Hsc70 in vivo, and the interaction between Hsp70/Hsc70 and hTid-1 is reduced after IFN-γ treatment. Furthermore, both hTid-1Sand hTid-1L can modulate IFN-γ-mediated transcriptional activity. IFN-γ participates in immune surveillance and tumor suppression (1Pestka S. Langer J.A. Zoon K.C. Samuel C.E. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 5C: 727-777Crossref Scopus (1593) Google Scholar, 2Stark G. Kerr I.M. Williams B.R.G. Silverman R.H. Schrieber R.D. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 227-264Crossref PubMed Scopus (3361) Google Scholar). Cook J.R. Garotta G. Cytokine Growth Factor Rev. 1997; 8: 189-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 4Soh J. Donnelly R.J. Kotenko S. Mariano T.M. Cook J.R. Wang N. Emanuel S.L. Schwartz B. Miki T. Pestka S. Cell. 1994; 76: 793-802Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Tyrosine kinases of the Janus kinase (Jak) family play a crucial role in signal transduction via cytokine receptors (5Ihle J.N. Kerr I.M. Trends Genet. 1995; 11: 69-74Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (818) Google Scholar). At present, the Jak family consists of four mammalian members Jak1, Jak2, Jak3, and Tyk2 (6Ihle J.N. Nature. 1995; 377: 591-594Crossref PubMed Scopus (1139) Google Scholar). A single Jak homologue has been identified inDrosophila as the gene associated with hopscotch(hop) mutations (7Binari R. Perrimin N. Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 300-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). Jaks appear to be constitutively associated with the membrane-proximal intracellular domains of cytokine receptors and become rapidly phosphorylated after ligand binding and dimerization or oligomerization of the receptor chains. This is followed by a cascade of events generating cytokine-mediated gene transcription. Activated Jaks phosphorylate tyrosine residues at distal parts of the intracellular domains of the receptor chains, thereby generating docking sites for signal transducers and activators of transcription (STATs) and other intracellular signaling molecules (8Darnell J.E. Science. 1997; 277: 1630-1635Crossref PubMed Scopus (3346) Google Scholar). STATs, which are recruited to the specific phosphotyrosine-containing motifs located in the cytoplasmic part of the receptors, are in turn phosphorylated by activated Jaks at distinct tyrosine residues (3Pestka S. Kotenko S.V. Muthukumaran G. Izotova L.S. Cook J.R. Garotta G. Cytokine Growth Factor Rev. 1997; 8: 189-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 8Darnell J.E. Science. 1997; 277: 1630-1635Crossref PubMed Scopus (3346) Google Scholar,9Kotenko S.V. Izotova L.S. Pollack B.P. Mariano T.M. Donnelly R.J. Muthukumaran G. Cook J.R. Garotta G. Silvennoinen O. Ihle J.N. Pestka S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 20915-20921Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). Following phosphorylation STATs form homo- and heterodimers then translocate to the nucleus and bind to specific response elements of genes leading to their transcriptional activation (8Darnell J.E. Science. 1997; 277: 1630-1635Crossref PubMed Scopus (3346) Google Scholar, 10Ihle J.N. Cell. 1996; 84: 331-334Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1262) Google Scholar). In addition to their role in cytokine signaling, Jak kinases may play a more diverse role in mammalian physiology. The Jaks are activated in response to acute pressure load suggesting a role for Jak kinases in cardiovascular physiology (11Pan J. Fukuda K. Kodama H. Makino S. Takahashi T. Sano M. Hori S. Ogawa S. Circ. Res. 1997; 81: 611-617Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). The Jaks have been linked to gliogenesis, consistent with a role for Jak kinases in central nervous system, and Jaks have been suggested to regulate potassium channels in response to prolactin (12Bonni A. Sun Y. Nadal Vicens M. Bhatt A. Frank D.A. Rozovsky I. Staht N. Yancopoulos G.D. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1997; 287: 477-483Crossref Scopus (853) Google Scholar, 13Cattaneo E. De Fraja C. Conti L. These observations support the hypothesis that Jak kinases have a variety of roles in signal transduction and possibly other events. A. 1999; 96: 8499-8504Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar).In the present report, we demonstrate that hTid-1 proteins (hTid-1S and hTid-1L) interact with Jak2in vivo. Furthermore, hTid-1S and hTid-1L interact with the IFN-γ receptor chain IFN-γR2 with which Jak2 remains associated. In addition, we show that hTid-1 interacts with the Hsp70/Hsc70 family of chaperones in IFN-γ-responsive HEp2 cells and the interaction is reduced in the presence of IFN-γ. We also present evidence that overexpression of the TID1 gene modulates IFN-γ-mediated signaling. Gundacker D. Rentrop M. Gateff E. Dev. Genet. 1995; 16: 64-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 25Schilling B. De-Medina T. Syken J. Vidal M. Munger K.
